needs_greek.label: Semi-Pelagianism

needs_greek.label: Free Choice (Liberum Arbitrium)

needs_greek.label: Will (Voluntas)

needs_greek.label: Intellect (Intellectus)

needs_greek.label: Synderesis
needs_greek.description: Mysterious medieval concept possibly from Jerome's mistranscription of Stoic syneidesis (moral consciousness). Scholastics debated whether synderesis is habit in intellect (Aquinas) or affective power

needs_greek.label: Absolute and Ordained Power (Potentia Absoluta et Ordinata)
needs_greek.description: Crucial scholastic distinction for understanding divine freedom and contingency of created order. De potentia absoluta, God could create different natural laws, different moral order, save/damn anyone

needs_greek.label: Synchronic Contingency

needs_greek.label: Diachronic Contingency
needs_greek.description: Aquinas' view: will necessarily follows last practical judgment of intellect. At the moment of choice, given that judgment, will necessarily chooses accordingly. But agent was free in earlier moments:

needs_greek.label: Occasionalism
needs_greek.description: Developed by Cartesians (especially Malebranche) to solve mind-body interaction problem. If mind and body are heterogeneous substances, they cannot causally interact. Solution: God causes bodily event

needs_greek.label: Intellectualism (Medieval)

needs_greek.label: Voluntarism (Medieval)

needs_greek.label: Bondage of the Will (Servum Arbitrium)
needs_greek.description: Central Reformation doctrine opposing Erasmian synergism. Luther argued the will is either servant of God or Satan—never neutral. Post-Fall, will necessarily sins unless liberated by grace. Salvation

needs_greek.label: Middle Knowledge (Scientia Media)

needs_greek.label: Physical Premotion (Praemotio Physica)
needs_greek.description: God moves secondary causes to their acts by a physical divine impulse that precedes and determines the effect. For free acts, this premotion is intrinsically efficacious and infallible, yet preserves

needs_greek.label: Liberty of Indifference (Libertas Indifferentiae)
needs_greek.description: Classical libertarian account of freedom. Descartes initially endorsed it as highest degree of freedom. Scholastics debated whether it's essential to freedom or merely its lowest degree (when will lac

needs_greek.label: Liberty of Spontaneity (Libertas Spontaneitatis)
needs_greek.description: Standard compatibilist account of freedom. Agent acts freely if: (1) action flows from agent's will/desires (spontaneity), (2) no external impediment prevents action (absence of constraint). Will's de

needs_both.label: Evil Inclination (Yetzer Ha-Ra)
needs_both.description: The 'evil inclination' or 'evil impulse' - human proclivity toward sin and selfishness. Not demonic possession but innate tendency. Rabbinic tradition (post-70 CE) develops doctrine of two inclination

needs_both.label: Good Inclination (Yetzer Ha-Tov)

needs_both.label: Choice/Free Will (Bechirah)
needs_both.description: Hebrew term for 'choice' or 'free will' - human capacity to choose between alternatives, especially between obedience and disobedience. Central to biblical covenant theology: God commands, humans choo

needs_both.label: Will/Desire (Ratzon)
needs_both.description: Hebrew term for 'will', 'desire', 'pleasure', 'favor'. Used of both divine will (ratzon Hashem) and human will. Central to understanding freedom as alignment of human will with divine will.

needs_both.label: Covenant Nomism
needs_both.description: E.P. Sanders' term for Jewish soteriological pattern: (1) God elects Israel and gives Torah; (2) Torah defines how to maintain covenant relationship; (3) obedience maintains but does not earn covenant

needs_both.label: Divine Providence (Hashgachah)

needs_both.label: Two Spirits Doctrine (Qumran)

needs_both.label: Acquisition (Kasb/Iktisab)
needs_both.description: Al-Ash'ari's solution to reconciling divine omnipotence with moral responsibility. God creates (khalq) both the power to act and the act itself in the human agent. The human 'acquires' (kasb) the act

needs_both.label: Transcendental Freedom

needs_both.label: Autonomy

needs_both.label: Categorical Imperative

needs_both.label: Agent Causation

needs_both.label: Self-Forming Actions (SFAs)

needs_both.label: Principle of Alternative Possibilities (PAP)

needs_both.label: Semicompatibilism

needs_both.label: Reactive Attitudes

needs_both.label: Hierarchical Mesh Theory

needs_both.label: Reasons-Responsiveness

needs_both.label: Readiness Potential (Bereitschaftspotential)

needs_both.label: Luck Argument

needs_both.label: Source vs. Leeway Freedom

needs_both.label: Free Will Illusionism

needs_both.label: Public Health-Quarantine Model of Criminal Justice

needs_both.label: Terminology Evolution: Greek → Latin Free Will Vocabulary

needs_both.label: Ultimate Responsibility (UR)
needs_both.description: Robert Kane's development of Aristotelian ultimate origination, requiring that agents be ultimate sources of their actions through self-forming actions (SFAs)

needs_both.label: Hierarchical Compatibilism

needs_both.label: Source Incompatibilism
needs_both.description: The view that determinism is incompatible with being the ultimate source of one's actions, developed from Alexander of Aphrodisias

needs_both.label: Manipulation Argument
needs_both.description: Modern incompatibilist argument (Pereboom) that manipulated agents lack free will. Develops ancient concerns about external causation.
